image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives

profileText: a Representative from Illinois; born in Chicago, Ill., March 5, 1925; graduated from Waller High School and studied business law at Northwestern University; served with Army Engineers in South Pacific during the Second World War; after being discharged, held positions with Cook County sheriff's department, the municipal court system, and the Board of Health; administrative assistant to health commissioner, 1963; alderman, Chicago city council, 1964-1970; elected simultaneously as a Democrat to the Ninety-first and to the Ninety-second Congress by special election, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of United States Representative Daniel J. Ronan and reelected to the succeeding Congress (November 3, 1970-December 8, 1972); died in an air crash during landing approach to Midway Airport, Chicago, Ill., December 8, 1972; interment in Burr Oak Cemetery, Aslip, Ill.; reinterred in Arlington National Cemetery, Arlington, Va.

asset.name: C000637_001
asset.creditLine: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: "George Washington Collins" in Black Americans in Congress, 1870-2007. Prepared under the direction of the Committee on House Administration by the Office of History & Preservation, U.S. House of Representatives. Washington: Government Printing Office, 2008.
Ralph Nader Congress Project. Citizens Look at Congress: George W. Collins, Democratic Representative from Illinois. Washington, D. C.: Grossman Publishers, 1972.

United States. 93d Congress, 1st session, 1973. House. Memorial services held in the House of Representatives of the United States, together with tributes presented in eulogy of George W. Collins, late a Representative from Illinois. Washington: Government Printing Office, 1973.

researchRecord.name: In the Cardiss Collins Papers, 1955-1998, 208.75 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: A small number of papers related to George Washington Collins are included in his wife's collection, the Cardiss Collins Papers. A finding aid for the Cardiss Collins Papers is available online.
